The happiness which virtue produces is perfect in itself and cannot be increased by the addition of these extemal possessions, nor lessened by their absence. On the other hand, they cannot confer happiness upon those who do not

possess virtue. The most wicked man may possess thern without being made either less wicked or unhappy by them; the virtuous man does not need them, his happiness is complete without.
